Description: Fragment of marble cuboid with inscription. The left upper corner is flat and slightly leant towards the front side (87 degrees to the upper side). A 2.3 cm high profile is broken off from the upper edge which could originally have been a roll moulding. On the front side the inscription A P T is deeply incised and filled with blue paint. Traces of red paint still remain on the groove below the upper moulding. The upper side and the left lateral surface are roughly flattened and the right side is fractured.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Perhaps from second temple of Apollo.)
Curator's comments: The architectural context is not easy due to the inclination of the front side. The syllable A P T indicates Artemis and the corresponding cult in the sanctuary of Apollo, however, it can also belong to a proper name. J. Boardman dates this inscription in the 4th century. Published (Petrie 1886, Pl. 14 A; Boardman 1959, AntJ 39, 204 NB 1).
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B427)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XIV A)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.37, p.338, fig. 7.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.46) (Phase 3)
